However, there is nothing in this bill to prevent a degree of subjectivity creeping into the decisions made by the conformity assessment bodies. That needs to be monitored closely. As I have just indicated, Australia will not be bound to accept the findings of the EC on a therapeutic device produced in one of its member states. This bill, once enacted, will merely provide the conformity assessment body with that option.

In many respects this agreement is similar to others to which Australia it already a party. In 1991 Australia became a member of the scheme for the mutual recognition of evaluation reports on pharmaceutical products, abbreviated to PER. June 1993 saw Australia enter another international agreement when it agreed to the pharmaceutical inspection convention. Both of these agreements made provisions for the mutual recognition of scientific and technical information with foreign organisations. But, as with this amendment, neither of these agreements have obliged the TGA to accept foreign therapeutic products on the basis of tests in the home country.

I will digress to refer to an example of recent problems with the TGA. Hyal Pharmaceutical Australia Ltd, a company based in my electorate in Western Australia, was delayed to the point of not being able to get approval from the TGA for a clinical trial of a drug that could have provided a breakthrough in the treatment of cancer.

Last year Hyal Pharmaceutical was denied the opportunity to conduct clinical trials in Australia using either Mitomycin and Hyalurnan, despite the fact that these same drugs are already being trialled in humans in Canada and Sweden. Further, these drugs were accepted for pre‐clinical submissions in the United States of America. All of these three countries conduct highly specialised and reputable testing procedures.

So capital raised in Australia, in seven figures, was sent offshore for a process that could well have been encouraged by a can-do attitude in the TGA in Australia. All the countries I have mentioned have seen fit to allow further trials of these drugs and yet Australia has baulked at the same opportunity despite being provided with a substantial amount of information on the history of the drugs in question.

This bill is unlikely to bring about a change in the mind-set of bureaucrats at the Therapeutic Goods Administration, but clearly one is required. I have indicated my support for this legislation and if it comes to a vote I will vote accordingly. However, I remind the government that this measure is only one small step down the road to creating a more receptive and effective TGA. Future policy must continue down the same track.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in support of the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1997, it is important to stress from the outset that the bill will lessen the time taken for Australian patients to wait for newly developed therapeutic goods and devices from European Community countries to be imported into Australia. Many people will view this as a very good thing. Secondly, the bill will give the Department of Health and Family Services the power to recall batches of drugs which do not meet Australian standards. This bill is an important one for the Australian people. It is important because it will enable potentially life saving, high quality drugs from within the European Community to be accessible much faster to Australian patients and health care workers.

SPEECH.PARA: It was a Liberal government which took up the responsibility of drug evaluation in the 1960s, and it is the current coalition government which is continuing to improve the deservedly high international reputation of the Therapeutic Goods Administration—or TGA, as I will refer to it from here on. As a result of the recent independent review of the TGA, this government has made a budget commitment to implement a range of reforms that will benefit businesses and consumers alike.

A major responsibility of the TGA is to regulate the supply of therapeutic goods in Australia. The intention of this is to protect health care workers and the Australian public by ensuring the safety, quality and effectiveness of therapeutic goods. In addition, the TGA has the ability to apply strict quality controls, evaluation and consistent monitoring of such goods and devices. I am sure that all honourable members will agree that there can be little doubt that the TGA has been highly effective in protecting the community from poor quality, unsafe and sometimes ineffective drugs.

All therapeutic goods being supplied to the Australian market—or being exported, for that matter—must be listed in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods, unless they have a specific exemption. Currently, there are some 24,000 drugs and 30,000 therapeutic devices on the Australian market. Approximately 3,000 new products are added each year; so it is understandable that to register any new product within the ARTG can take a considerable time. Significantly, amendments Nos 8 to 13 will continue to uphold the fine safety standards of the TGA. Equally, they will enable therapeutic goods and devices from the European Community to be assessed by certain approved overseas bodies, thus reducing the considerable time and expense taken for the TGA to evaluate these products.

The bill is reflective of the government's desire to protect and promote public health and enhance the viability of Australian industry. Fundamental to this legislation is the government's international Agreement on Mutual Recognition in Relation to Conformity Assessment, Certificates and Markings between Australia and the European Community. This will cover not only therapeutic goods but six other industry sectors. When finalised, Australia will be the first country outside of Europe to sign an agreement of this kind within the European Community.

The amendments cover therapeutic devices and therapeutic goods. Therapeutic devices commonly include products ranging from dental materials, bandages, catheters and condoms to imaging equipment. Under the bill, if a therapeutic device is produced in the European Community and a conformity assessment certificate stating that the item meets all Australian standards is provided by a European assessment body recognised here in Australia, the secretary of the Department of Health and Family Services must include the device on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. The device is then allowed onto the Australian market. In the event of the device not being allowed onto the market, the secretary must notify the importer within 28 days in writing.

For therapeutic goods, however—goods which commonly include drugs, herbal remedies and similar products—the bill will continue procedures put in place under an earlier convention between Australia and a number of European countries. Under this convention, the secretary of the department will take into account a certificate from a relevant body which states that the therapeutic good meets Australian standards. However, the secretary is not obliged to allow the product's importation simply because of this certification.

These amendments reflect the government's overall commitment to create a more streamlined regulatory system for drug evaluation, providing increased flexibility, greater efficiencies and enhanced international competitiveness of the Australian industry. It should be noted that these amendments stemmed from the recommendations made by Professor Peter Baume, who conducted the 1991 inquiry seeking improvements into the drug evaluation process in the TGA. His subsequent report, A question of balance: report on the future of drug evaluation in Australia, showed that changes were required in the organisation so as to make the TGA's review process of drugs more efficient within the agency's existing resource limits.

Moreover, it was apparent from the report at the time that industry was concerned that government regulations were creating unwarranted delays to approval of products and had little sympathy or regard for the needs of business. I might add that this view has been echoed time and time again by various businesses struggling to operate effectively under a Labor government. Five years after the report the situation has changed markedly. Many of the recommendations made by Professor Baume are being adopted by the TGA. Drug evaluation time has already been considerably reduced. The Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1997 will reduce time and expense for drug evaluation even further, while upholding the strict safety standards and quality controls which have made this evaluation process among the best in the world.

Another important amendment in the bill will give the secretary of the Department of Health and Family Services the power to withdraw batches of goods where they fail to meet applicable statutory standards. Currently, there are two options if recall procedures are necessary. Firstly, the goods are cancelled from the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods and recalled or, secondly, the manufacturer or other relevant body, known as the sponsor, will be prosecuted for supplying goods which do not conform to the required standards. This measure will allow the secretary to recall the batch of goods which do not comply to standards, providing there have been no similar lapses by the sponsor within the last six months. The amendment will be a benefit because of the TGA's ability to respond far more quickly to recall goods without recourse to the somewhat draconian procedures currently in place.

In summarising my remarks, this bill demonstrates the government's commitment to ensuring that Australian health standards compare with the best in the world. The cooperative measures we are taking internationally will benefit both the Australian people and our industry, and I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mrs MOYLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to thank honourable members for the contribution that they have made to the debate, and also take the opportunity to answer a point that was made by the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) in his speech when he referred to the TGA taking 255 days to retest products that already had been tested overseas. I inform the member that the TGA does not retest the products but rather examines the results of the overseas tests, and the data is accepted in the same format as that it is lodged in in Europe. While 255 days is allowed, the TGA is taking on average about 160 days, which is consistent with the times taken both in the UK and the USA. The recent review of the TGA undertaken by the government is addressing further improvements in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 2 June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIAMS
TALKER.ROLE: Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.
The Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill 1996 seeks to amend the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 to facilitate a commitment made by the government in its pre‐election policy statements.

The bill would amend the Broadcasting Services Act to ensure that the minister's power to direct the ABA to conduct investigations can extend to an investigation of future regulatory arrangements and policy directions in respect of on‐line services. This is an interim measure, pending government consideration of a comprehensive regulatory framework for on‐line services.

The current directions power in section 171 of the act provides some scope for the ABA to be directed to investigate the regulation of matters that the act does not cover. However, generally speaking, such investigations must be incidental to the operation or administration of the current act. In relation to services not covered by the act, such as on‐line services, this limits the role of the ABA to making recommendations about provisions that the act should make for those services, as it did in its June 1996 report, Investigation into the content of on‐line services. The act does not authorise a broader ABA investigation, in consultation with industry, into matters that might be included in codes of practice as part of a future regulatory regime.

Consistent with its election policy commitment, Australia On‐line, the government proposes to introduce a regulatory framework for the on‐line industry incorporating codes of practice and supervised by the ABA. The proposed new directions power will allow the minister to direct the ABA to investigate suitable codes of practice, pending the development of legislation implementing the government's policy.

The proposed new section 171 will allow the minister to direct the ABA in writing to investigate any matter in respect of which the parliament is able to make laws under the `postal, telegraphic and other like services' power in paragraph 51(v) of the constitution. In particular, the minister will be able to direct the ABA to investigate any matter relating to the future regulation or operation of telecommunications services, including on‐line services.

The provisions in the bill have been drafted broadly to give the minister the flexibility to issue a range of investigation directions to the ABA that are consistent with evolving government policy on the future regulation of on‐line services. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very fitting that the Attorney‐General moved the second reading of the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill 1996, given that the alternative regulator to the Australian Broadcasting Authority to examine on‐line services was probably the Attorney‐General's Department and the Office of Film and Literature Classification. To have the Attorney‐General move the second reading is very appropriate and is worthy of consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last government, I had the honour of being the minister for communications and the arts. As minister, I requested that the Australian Broadcasting Authority carry out an investigation into this subject. The Broadcasting Authority's report, Investigation into the content of on‐line services, has helped contribute to the debate on the best way to regulate on‐line services in Australia. The opposition supports the legislation because it seeks to put beyond any doubt the fact that the Australian Broadcasting Authority is the right organisation to ensure that the public interest is protected in regulating on‐line services.

You would be aware, Madam Deputy Speaker, that developments in technology have, in the last decade, raised a number of controversial issues about censorship and the way in which we try to protect the public interest. Computer games and then CD‐ROM based games raised a series of issues about censorship that needed to be dealt with. The classification system for books and magazines is rarely used these days. The classification system for films and television seeks to protect the public interest. While it raises matters of some controversy on occasion, overall I think it works reasonably well.

Some of the new computer games are quite distasteful. There are a number of games that have been prohibited for release in Australia that were X and R rated by the Office of Film and Literature Classification and I think most members of both sides of the parliament would support the continuing prohibition of those sorts of games. A classification system that rates those games as MA down to G gives parents good advice when they are looking for birthday presents or Christmas presents for their children, and that is something which has worked well.

The difficulty comes with on‐line services in that it is almost impossible to regulate the Internet. It is almost impossible to regulate on‐line services and for that reason we have to be concerned about some of the material that becomes available, and not just to adults but to children, whether at home or at school, who can use the Internet.

It is common knowledge that if people search for the right words young children can find recipes to build bombs. People in the past have been convicted in the courts in Australia for downloading child pornography, and there are examples of material that vilify particular races. Other allegations have been made that people's reputations have been defamed and their reputations sullied because of material that has been anonymously placed on the Internet.

The great difficulty that we as legislators have is that it is almost impossible to take material off the Internet or make it not accessible to people using on‐line services. We can only pass laws for Australia. We cannot pass laws that control what someone might do in Fiji, the United States, Canada, Kazakhstan or China—or other countries beyond the legislative reach of the Australian parliament.

There has been discussion in some other countries where they have tried to put the legal obligation on the Internet service provider to ensure that their customers—adults or children— cannot get access to material that is inappropriate, whether it is pornographic or vilifies particular races or other material that might be inappropriate for children.

The difficulty that those debates have established is that the company that provides access to the Internet is placed at risk of simply being closed down because, like the Australian parliament, the Internet service provider cannot prohibit particular areas that people can visit if they are surfing the Internet. Most countries that have considered placing legal obligations on the Internet service providers have baulked at that because they realise such a move is impractical and so they have tried to look for other solutions.

One of the most promising of the solutions is the work being done by a number of the major computer software companies that are seeking to develop software filters. Parents could install the filters at home, or schools could make sure that they use the software that tries to limit the range and access that young children have when they are surfing the Internet. One day we might even have ratings for particular sites on the Internet which could be implemented through some new software. It is not with us yet but it might come one day.

This legislation gives the Broadcasting Authority the power to investigate a new area, that is, on-line services. An old area that I think the Australian Broadcasting Authority should have investigated is one that is mandated in the current Broadcasting Services Act. The current act actually requires the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, before 1 July 1997, to conduct an inquiry into whether or not there should be a sixth high-powered commercial television channel in each of the major capital cities. I do not know if Senator Alston intends to conduct this inquiry in the six days remaining, and I do not know if he will be in breach of the act if he does not conduct that inquiry within the next six days but, to the best of my knowledge, the government decided soon after its election that it had ruled out consideration of the sixth high‐powered channel. I do not know whether the department gave advice to the minister and that was the inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —He asked Ian and I what we think.

—The minister might have asked the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) and that might have been the extent of the inquiry. I am not sure if the minister asked people whose companies might be within the electorate of the member for North Sydney, and that might have been the extent of the inquiry. I certainly think it was the intention of the parliament that there would be a public inquiry, probably run by the Australian Broadcasting Authority or the Department of Communications and the Arts, which would have allowed full and adequate debate of what was in the public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: I am one of those who subscribe to the view that Australia is served well by our mix of public, commercial and community broadcasters. In the United States, they have a very strong commercial television network and a very weak public system. PBS in the United States produces the odd good program, but it is nowhere near as strong as the ABC and SBS are in Australia.

Britain has gone too far the other way. Until recently, BBC provided the two commercial networks and there was one alternative commercial television network in Britain. They now have a number of others competing with BBC1 and BBC2. In Britain traditionally their public sector has been too strong and the commercial sector too weak compared with the situation in Australia. Part of the reason for the success of pay TV in Britain is the traditional dominance of the BBC.

BREAK.PARA: In Australia, despite the fact that many people are unhappy about the quality of the programs they get, especially during non‐rating periods, on average we can be proud of the success of public, commercial and community broadcasting, particularly in television. One of the reasons the Australian television production industry has been able to produce quality Australian dramas and sporting coverage of very high technical calibre is that we have a successful mix of public and commercial television broadcasting in Australia.

Certainly, channels 7, 9 and 10 would argue that if there were a fourth commercial network competing with them, it would spread the advertising revenue available for television more thinly. That would mean that each of them would have less money to spend commissioning Australian drama and to spend on journalists running around to car accidents and murder stories, as well as on the odd journalist based at a bureau in Macquarie Street or in Canberra. They would argue that that would then affect the quality of commercial television in Australia.

The fact that the Australian commercial networks are quite profitable at the moment is one issue that should be taken into consideration. I am disappointed that, to date, with six days to go, we have not had the opportunity of a public investigation of these issues.

What is also interesting—and an issue I would hope the member for North Sydney or the minister in summing up could address—is whether or not the former government provided an instrument to the Australian Broadcasting Authority to conduct a public investigation into this very issue. My recollection is that in January 1996 I signed an instrument directing the ABA to carry out a public investigation into this issue. I am not quite sure if that instrument was revoked or what the legal status is of that direction to the Australian Broadcasting Authority. I do not think it was revoked by a change of government. I do not know whether Senator Alston, as the new Minister for Communications and the Arts, revoked that instruction.

I would like, perhaps when the minister sums up, to have that legal position qualified, given that we do have six days left before 1 July when the government is legally obliged to conduct what I thought would be a public inquiry into whether there should be a fourth commercial network in Australia. That is another issue that the Australian Broadcasting Authority could be examining as a result of the powers that it already has. This amendment seeks to make it clear that the Broadcasting Authority can conduct investigations into on‐line services, an issue that is going to be increasingly important in Australia.

The other issue to bear in mind is that when people think of on‐line services, they think that we are talking about services that children at school or some computer nerds might use when they have time to spare. They might use it to search for papers or text, but many people consider that the current system is too slow and therefore it is not something that will be very attractive to many Australians for the foreseeable future.

Those people do not understand that under the concept of convergence that many people talk about, the Internet and computer services will not just be text. At the moment you can obtain photographs and audio grabs and even some short video clips over the Internet, but it takes a very long time for the material to be received by your computer at home or at a child's computer in school.

In the not too distant future the cost of communications will be so low that people will be able to afford very rapid communications links with the Internet. That will mean a user will be able to click on a particular item and call up not just text or a photo but television quality video. That is the convergence between computers and television that is being talked about. Madam Deputy Speaker, imagine you miss the ABC 7 o'clock news because you get home late after being at a number of ethnic functions in your electorate—working hard, as we all know. So you call up the ABC news and when you play the first story, you do not like it because it is another example of the Howard government having broken core promises—it is so familiar. So you hit the fast forward button and you go on to the next story straightaway. Imagine being able to program your television set so that you were able to select the stories that you wanted—for example, the foreign affairs stories because of your interest in those issues. The whole idea of a television set that you turn on and that washes programs over you will be thrown out the door.

That is the convergence that is coming. On‐line services will not be just text with the odd photo and a slow audio or video clip; they will give full video quality material. All sorts of new opportunities will be opened up. Imagine school children doing their assignments being able to call up from the National Library a copy of Captain Bligh's journal from when he was set adrift—or a copy of the member for North Sydney's maiden speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whatever it takes.

—A good double, I suspect, Captain Bligh and the member for North Sydney. Or perhaps if school children in the electorate of the member for North Sydney were doing an assignment on how Australian life has changed or how living in Sydney has changed, they could call up some of the early footage of the streetscapes in Sydney from the National Film and Sound Archive. That is part of Australia's heritage and if we can make that material more widely available to kids, especially those in outback remote and rural areas, I am sure it would be of great benefit and importance to their education.

BREAK.PARA: We are saying that if the kids are to have access to that quality of material we also need to be reassured that they are not going to be looking up formulas for building fertiliser bombs and having others seeking to use the Internet to distribute child pornography or racist material. They are the protections that we would like to see software companies working on. A number of schools already have intranets that do try to manage access. Many of those schools are doing a very responsible job in making sure kids develop the skills they will need to use this technology in the future, but they are seeking to make sure that it is done in a responsible manner.

Giving these powers to the ABA ensures that we have a regulator which is very responsible and one which is seeking to make sure that public interest is protected. It is legislation that the Labor Party supports very strongly.

TALK.START.PARA: —To respond to the question from the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) about the possible ABA inquiry into the sixth television licence, my understanding is that the ABA has consulted with a number of people. In fact, only in the last couple of days there have been some reports in the Sydney Morning Herald that Grundy Television has been interested in purchasing the sixth licence for $200 million. What a surprise that would be, given that, as the former minister for communications and the arts is well aware, the licence is everything in the value of a television station with free to air broadcasts. When, as I understand it, you have the Network Ten group with net tangible assets of $44 million and the ATN‐Channel 7 network with net tangible assets of around $130‐odd million, you can just see, on the multiples they are trading on on the Australian Stock Exchange and the value of the company, that the value of a television station is overwhelmingly in the licence which gives them access to the broader Australian market.

BREAK.PARA: Over the past decade the telecommunications industry has experienced unprecedented growth and change throughout the world, and in Australia in particular. Recent developments in telecommunications technologies are nothing short of revolutionary. High‐speed computer networks and major advances in the physical facilities that transport data, such as fibre optics and high bandwidth satellite transmission, offer the possibility of universal information access and interactive two‐way communication in a way never before possible.

The astounding rate of technological change and convergence in communications media shows no immediate sign of abating. It seems that the latest boom promises to be in satellite based communications services. An article published in the 3 March edition of US News and World Report reported that Craig McCaw, who is a cellular phone tycoon, and Bill Gates, whom we all know, have joined forces to invest in a $US9 billion satellite scheme which will provide broadband connections. They are the kind that are transmitted over fibre‐optic cables at the astounding rate of megabits per second—that is, a thousand times faster than the current dial‐up connection.

What is particularly attractive about satellites is their egalitarian nature. You do not have to be in a highly industrialised area of the world to enjoy their benefits, so the people in Caboolture or the people in Coonabarabran will enjoy the same access to information. Satellite based communications can take the place of thousands of kilometres of terrestrial telephone lines. Therefore, more sophisticated satellite based communications services appear to be the next communications media that will radically change the way the world lives.

Recently I was in Hong Kong and visited Star TV, which is a broad satellite service that has the potential to broadcast to two‐thirds of the world's population. Much of what the member for Dobell was speaking about in terms of the advancement of interactive television and communications services is already starting. Star TV is a very good example, where the consumer is starting to have some more direct input into the shows that are available in their homes. Currently, Star TV broadcasts to 63 million homes and it has the potential to broadcast to a much broader audience, covering China and India, the two most densely and highly populated countries in the world, as well as most of Asia. Therefore, the opportunity for satellite TV to expand communications around the world is almost boundless.

Australians as a group are among the world's leaders in the rate at which they have embraced and adopted emerging communications technologies. These changes have altered the way in which we live, the way we do business and the way we communicate with each other. The existence of on‐line communications services, such as the Internet, has changed the nature of communications from a few individuals speaking to the many through traditional mass media to the many speaking to the many. On‐line services have brought a medium for publication to the ordinary person. Today, as Mr Ethan Katsh, an Internet advocate, has put it, with access to a computer, a modem and a phone line we can `wander the earth and never leave home'.

The most popular and well‐known on‐line service today, of course, is the Internet. It is hard to find a concise and understandable definition of what exactly the Internet is, but the following description by Lewis M. Branscomb, former chief scientist of IBM, is one of the better ones that I have seen. He says:

The Internet is best thought of as a suite of digital communications—packet switching protocols that when adopted by many nonhomogenous digital networks, create the equivalent of a virtual, interactive overlay network. The Internet is not a physical network. It has no owner, no control point, sells no services. Thus the Internet is better thought of not as a network, but as a remarkably powerful array of internetworking capabilities, through which great numbers of users can reach one another and a great array of sources of information around the world through the facilities of many networks.

The Internet originated out of a US Department of Defense program to explore ways of building networks that could survive partial destruction—for example, from a nuclear attack. Each of the networks was presumptively unreliable and on the failure of one system the data packets would automatically be redirected through the remaining links.

The number of networks that comprise the Internet has dramatically increased over the past decade. Whereas in 1981 fewer than 300 computers were linked to the Internet, today there are approximately 9½ million. While estimates are probably unreliable, due to its extraordinary growth, it is estimated that around 60 million individuals have access of some kind to the Internet. In July 1996, it was estimated that Australians represented approximately one million of these 60 million, making us the fourth largest user of the Internet worldwide. By the year 2000, some Internet analysts estimate that there could be between 500 and 800 million Internet users worldwide, and one billion to 1.25 billion users by the year 2005.

A variety of communications services are available on‐line, including electronic mail, which most of us would be familiar with, and intranet—such as the one operated by the department of education in New South Wales—LISTSERVs, USENET newsgroups, bulletin boards, real‐time Internet Relay Chat, file transfer protocol or FTP, as it is known, the World Wide Web and Telnet. A number of these services form a part of our everyday lives here in parliament. Many senators and members, including me, and parliamentary departments have home pages on the World Wide Web. My colleague the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron) has an excellent home page—

TALK.START.PARA: —An excellent home page.

—The member for Stirling and I have been talking about the opportunities to further develop our own interactive home pages over the next few months. In addition, three of the five parliamentary departments enjoy access to an in‐house network that is, of course, an intranet. Most on‐line communications are for non‐commercial purposes. However, since the arrival of the World Wide Web, businesses have grown more interested in cyberspace. For example, the 8 March edition of the Economist reported that Chrysler, the US car manufacturer, predicts that within four years one‐quarter of its total car sales will be made on‐line by car buyers who completely bypass showrooms.

BREAK.PARA: In a report released in late 1995 by Cutler and Company, an organisation that has contributed substantially to the debate on the opportunities that exist for Australia on the information superhighway, it was estimated that the value of on‐line purchases in the US alone will be around $1.65 billion by the year 2000. The development of on‐line services in Australia and elsewhere has not followed the model of traditional telecommunications or broadcasting. Whereas telecommunications and broadcasting have had a significant history of involvement in regulation by government, on‐line services essentially have been driven by market forces and user demand.

Thus, in Australia and elsewhere, on‐line mediated communications in many ways do not fit precisely within existing telecommunications or broadcasting regulatory regimes. Things become more confusing, due to the trend towards the convergence of technology. Today, distinctions between broadcasting, telecommunications, satellite, computer and pay TV technologies have blurred. In addition, convergence in hardware platforms allows access to both television and on‐line services. In the near future, cellular phones will include touch‐screen Internet access.

Technological developments and service trends since the implementation of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 have led to an examination of the extent to which the on‐line service information and entertainment broadcasting services are accommodated under the act. This was one of the three major issues specifically addressed in the ABA report Investigation into the content of on‐line services, which was presented to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, in June 1996.

The ABA report, prepared at the direction of the member for Dobell, the former minister for communications, reported on and made recommendations with respect to, firstly, the content of on‐line information and entertainment broadcasting services; secondly, technological advances and service trends in the provision of on‐line information and entertainment services by the broadcasting industry; and, thirdly, as I noted a little earlier, the extent to which on‐line information and broadcasting services are accommodated by the operation of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. The ABA report has been hailed as one of the most comprehensive studies ever done on the nature of on‐line services and the implications of content based regulations.

The ABA report noted among other things that on‐line mediated communications are distinguishable from other forms of communications media in a number of important ways that affect the way in which regulation of these services fits into the existing legislation. For example, the Internet is by design a decentralised, self‐maintaining place that transports data without direct human involvement in any single defined place. It is without a single administrator, central storage location, control point, or communications channel.

Therefore, unlike a traditional broadcasting service provider, an Internet service provider does not control information programming or content. In that regard, the Internet can be distinguished from radio and television broadcasting—which, as traditionally a one‐to‐many or point‐to‐multipoint technology, transmits audio or video programs from a single broadcaster to many users.

Another distinguishing feature of cyberspace communications is the very different way in which content is delivered in the on‐line environment. When browsing the World Wide Web, for example, a user generally must take several steps to receive information. As the ABA report noted, content is not received passively as in broadcast radio and television. In that regard, it has been noted by one observer that the nature of communications through on‐line services shifts:

. . . the locus of editorial control from broadcasters and publishers towards viewers and users . . . Rather than having their choices made by a broadcaster or a publisher, users of video and print data bases . . . have access to much of the raw information itself, without the filter of a newspaper or a television news program.

In effect, this new world will take the editors out of the newspapers and the program managers out of the television news services. The Macquarie Dictionary defines `broadcast' as `disseminate widely'. In the world of broadcasting, the term was generally understood to mean `disseminate information over the airwaves', because that was the way in which radio and television communications were traditionally transmitted.

The principal act however, extended the meaning of `broadcasting service'. One of the many conclusions set forth in the ABA's report is that many on‐line services are, in effect, on‐demand services and consequently do not come within the definition of `broadcasting services' in the principal act. Therefore, legislative amendments are necessary to clarify the powers and functions of the minister and the ABA in relation to the regulation of on‐line services.

In that regard, the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill 1996 will amend the Broadcasting Services Act to ensure that the minister's power to direct the ABA to conduct investigations can extend to an investigation of future regulatory arrangements and policy directions in respect of on‐line services. As noted in the second reading speech, this is intended to be an interim measure, pending government consideration of a comprehensive regulatory framework for on‐line services.

The current directions power in section 171 of the principal act provides some degree of scope for the ABA to be directed to investigate the regulation of matters that the principal act does not cover. Such investigations, however, must generally be incidental to the operation and administration of the principal act.

The government intends to introduce a regulatory framework for the on‐line industry, incorporating codes of practice supervised by the ABA. The proposed new directions power will allow the minister to direct the ABA to investigate suitable codes of practice, pending the development of legislation. This is a terribly important matter, given that technology is advancing faster than we as regulators can regulate it. With that in place, it is important that the minister, the government and this parliament try to be one or two steps ahead of the game and anticipate what may be upcoming changes in the technological environment that will provide on‐line services to the Australian people.

I am not suggesting for a moment that we should be in the business of social engineering. I am not suggesting for a moment that we should be trying to introduce legislation prior to the market development of new technology. What I am suggesting is that a certain amount of flexibility should be provided to the Australian Broadcasting Authority and to the minister, so that they can anticipate some of the problems that are going to arise with the development of on‐line services.

Proposed new section 171(1) will enable the minister to direct the ABA, in writing, to investigate any matter in respect of which the parliament has power to make laws under the `postal, telegraphic and other like services' power in section 51(v) of the constitution. Proposed new section 171(2)(b) will confirm that the minister may direct the ABA to investigate `any matter relating to the future regulation or operation of a telecommunications service'.

On‐line communications services and technologies are at an early and rapidly evolving stage in their development. Future trends are impossible to predict with even a moderate degree of certainty. It is therefore imperative that we take the best approach towards the regulation of on‐line services, which is to proceed in a particularly thoughtful and informed manner.

Unlike our counterparts in Washington DC, this government has wisely avoided a knee‐jerk legislative response towards the regulation of on‐line services. I am referring, of course, to the United States Communications Decency Act, known as the CDA. This act has been involved in litigation since minutes after President Clinton signed it into law in February last year. In June, a three‐judge federal panel declared several parts of the act unconstitutional and granted a temporary restraining order prohibiting the US Justice Department from enforcing, or even investigating, violations of the CDA. The constitutional validity of this statute is now being considered by the US Supreme Court.

Critical elements of a workable policy framework in the area of on‐line services are flexibility and ability to adapt to rapid change. The government is committed to remaining informed as to the direction of the on‐line services industry and to ensure that it is up to date on matters affecting its future. In that regard, the minister has formed an advisory body, the Information Policy Advisory Council, known as IPAC. IPAC members include some of Australia's leading information and communications experts.

There is no greater challenge for a government than to keep up with the rapid changes in modern society. In the 21st century, technological change will continue to be so rapid that no government could hope to maintain an inflexible regulatory regime. In this case, I congratulate the minister for the amendment bill, which maintains a level of flexibility in the regulation of on‐line services. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hardgrave, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly a great pleasure to follow my learned colleague and friend the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey). He is a very practical fellow and has hit a number of the important nails of this debate right on the head. He is quite right when he suggests that technology is changing faster than any regulatory regime can possibly hope to keep up with. He is also quite right when he says that the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill 1996 is about trying to anticipate the potential changes which may come and providing the flexibility and the broad scope that is needed for government to cope with the many new technological services that are going to be available to each and every one of us.

SPEECH.PARA: For those sorts of reasons, I am very pleased to speak to this bill. It is another example of the government's sensible and logical approach to dealing with technological change in Australia now and into the future. It is also another fulfilment of a pre‐election commitment to look at the matter of on‐line services. It sets out some interim measures, essentially so that we can kick-start the future and make some future planning. New technology is constantly emerging and keeping up with that is a very difficult matter.

Section 171 is about changing the principal act to provide scope for the Australian Broadcasting Authority to look further into matters outside the lines of its current restrictions. Currently, the ABA is somewhat limited in its ability to investigate and plan matters such as on‐line services.

One of the key conclusions of the ABA report to the government last year Investigation into the content of on‐line services was that many on‐line services cannot be controlled by the ABA because they are demand services and are not covered by the definition of a broadcast service. That is, consumers have the ability to pick and choose the content that they actually consume. That particular provision is contained in paragraph 6(1)(b) of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. This section states that the broadcasting service does not include a service that makes programs including a dial‐up service available on demand on a point-to-point basis.

This bill clarifies the powers and functions of both the minister and the ABA in relation to these sorts of matters. This will include the Internet, which will be defined as a telecommunications service and have the same meaning as that contained in the Telecommunications Act 1991; that is, it is a service for carrying communications by means of a guided or unguided electromagnetic energy, or both.

This is all about people power. The ABA will be given the power to call for written submissions from the public in respect of its investigations. Of course, there is tremendous interest quantified by the contribution from the member for North Sydney in matters such as on‐line services.

BREAK.PARA: The coalition policy prior to the election and now being fulfilled in government is about wider access and lower prices for digital connectivity. They are the keys to the government's on‐line industry policy. The government is undertaking a number of other measures in concert with this. It is reviewing the best means of delivering comparable services outside the future mode of operation areas by investigating the most appropriate lowest cost technical options. The government is also establishing a Commonwealth‐state on‐line government council—an OGC—under the Council of Australian Governments, which will have the role of coordinating government efforts, encouraging collaboration where appropriate, and avoiding costly duplication.

The government is also consulting the states and territories to implement a new restructuring government program for the application of on‐line technology to the areas of government information and cultural and social services. An inquiry into the extent of information gathering in the public and private sectors, the uses to which it is put, and the commercial forces which are driving it will also be launched. This particular inquiry will present arguments and options to the government on privacy policies which will strike a balance between the legitimate interests of public and commercial organisations on the one hand and the legitimate rights of individuals on the other.

The government has a multifaceted approach to this particular industry and also to content regulation of the on‐line industry, in consultation with the community, the on‐line industry itself, the states and territories, including the establishment of industry codes of practice. Also, community media will be given a role in the on‐line environment with a more stable policy framework and investment in electronic infrastructure which will ensure community access to the on‐line media and encourage entry level training.

Essentially, this is all about a new regime and the future. It will allow the minister to direct the ABA to investigate the `what ifs' and the possibilities of seeking broadly the views of the community, with all the various aspirations and ideas that are floating around amongst people who are very enthusiastic about Internet and on‐line services.

The powers embodied within the constitution, in section 51(v), prescribe that the Commonwealth has a role to play in postal, telegraph and related services. Of course, when that wonderful living, breathing document, the constitution, was written there was no thought of the use of spectrum or things like the Internet. I guess that in so many ways the constitution has been challenged in years past and the High Court has settled the matter of the right of the Feds to make laws about radio and television. So the Commonwealth has control of the spectrum and manages the spectrum, and no‐one disagrees with that.

In many ways, the ABA in the past has been pretty sluggish in anticipating what could come. In a lot of ways this bill will ensure that the ABA responds, and is given the encouragement to respond, to what could be the future. With some of the more general broadcast media, such as the AM and FM bands, the ABA has been a bit slow to open up their potential. New technology, such as digital transmissions, will allow more players and allow more people to get involved in accessing the AM and FM bands. That will probably mean, providing the ABA allows it, that we will have a greater diversity of media voices in every market. But the ABA will probably need a hurry‐on by government to ensure that that particular event occurs.

When you add it all up, when you look at the Internet, on‐line services, the potential space that is not being used in the broadcast spectrums which the government, because of the constitution, is allowed to look after, there are a lot of implications for cross‐media ownership. The debate which is going on at the moment is a very important one, and there is a variety of views on it. I guess no‐one here will disagree that, no matter what happens as a result of any changes which may come to the ownership of media outlets in this country, there will always be major owners, major players and major media. But what is very important is that government provides a lead to ensure there is an additional range of voices, that there is diversity, plurality and accessibility so that average Australians are able to gain a range of views without too much difficulty. That is where on‐line services certainly have a role to play and can assist in the provision of diversity of outlets.

In the cross‐media ownership debate there is certainly a lot of discussion about ownership. Ownership variety is not necessarily the absolute answer to ensuring a diversity of views. Rather, there needs to be a broad range of outlets available. The radio spectrum is one of the options. In fact, compared to the cost of gearing up for a new television network or new newspaper chain, the radio spectrum provides, after the Internet, perhaps the cheapest form of entry and perhaps the cheapest possibilities for ensuring additional diversity.

The area of telecommunications in this country is a very exciting one; the future has exponential potential. There is no doubt that it is difficult to fully forecast where the changes in technology will lead to the growth of new media, and whether it is the moguls who are going to own the new media or the people who are going to be empowered by the processes that are before us today. They are very important matters which have to be discussed fully.

The Internet provides one of the great empowerments of the average person. It provides, if you like, a devolution of power away from the major media—providing, of course, that people are able to gain access to the Internet; that they are able, without too many cost prohibitions, to freely gain access to the range of views which can and no doubt will be, and already are, being expressed through the Internet and on‐line services. The Internet, if promoted, if made possible, if made accessible, has a very important role to play in our community. For all these reasons, it is quite right that the government should provide a great deal of flexibility to the Broadcasting Authority to review and to consider the range of options and matters associated with the growth in the use of the Internet in Australia.

There are a number of matters that should also concern all honourable members. Gambling transactions and the availability of intellectual property on the Internet are matters which need to be looked at very closely. The Internet and its use and access encroaches on a range of federal government departments and a number of state government departments. For example, the Attorney‐General's Department has an interest in it, obviously. The Department of Communications and the Arts is interested and Treasury should also be interested. Trade, Customs, Industry, Science and Technology, Administrative Services and even Foreign Affairs should all have an interest in what should come from any inquiry into the use of the Internet in Australia.

The Internet is, after all, the great tax evader tool of the present day, and potentially into the future, with literally millions of transactions taking place each and every year beyond the reach of the taxation department, thereby allowing people to evade wholesale sales tax and even financial institution duties.

People told me recently how they were able to access, via the Internet, a particular compact disc from a record store operating in New York city and it was in Australia inside four days—in fact, four compact discs were inside Australia within four days—and that transaction was paid for via the Internet through typing in a credit card number, but no tax was paid to the Australian government in the process. So the implication of the Internet for government revenue is also a matter that really must be looked at very closely.

When you consider that the Department of Administrative Services is spearheading the government's attempts to promote electronic commerce, so that transactions with government can also be done electronically through mechanisms such as the Internet, there are important ramifications from that. Then there are the censorship matters—I do not want to dwell on them but certainly a lot of people express quite justifiable concerns about minors gaining access to certain pages—that should be looked at very closely by government.

Copyright is another matter which concerns me, and I am sure the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron), as we are both former working journalists. We understand the right of access to material that is generated by journalists, writers and artists but also the need to ensure that their copyright and their rights to their work are not infringed by the Internet, and because of tax evasion.

It is certainly time for the government to act, and they are acting through the broad parameters of this bill. The bill helps to capture the imagination of many people in our nation, including a lot of young Australians. Younger Australians, understandably, are taking to newer technology faster perhaps than many older Australians. Young Australians, no doubt, will welcome the passage of this bill and the support that it is receiving from both sides of this place. It is certainly a proactive matter and will establish a new regime which will allow the minister to deal with the broad range of issues, some of which I have outlined in my contribution today. It is certainly all about helping Australians recognise the potential benefits as well as some of the potential pitfalls of on‐line services and their massive growth in this country. It is also helping the community to take part in the debate about the potential powerful role of the Internet in our society.

As I said at the beginning of my contribution, the bill before us today is the realisation of another election commitment. A number of other commitments we made in relation to this area include the formation of an Information Policy Advisory Council to advise the minister directly on certain matters. The IPAC will look at rural and regional access to the sorts of services that the Internet can provide and the impact of on‐line services on the service industry sector. It will also look at on‐line security. This advisory council includes senior people from the industry with a wealth of experience and knowledge.

Minister Alston should be congratulated for the cooperation that he is seeking with ministers in the states and territories, and even with local government, and for the leadership which he, on behalf of the government, is determined to show on the issues affecting access and electronic commerce.

The bill comes before us today at a very critical time in the development of the Internet and its potential for Australia, a country that is well‐placed because of its large land mass and, for a lot of Australians, its very sparse population coverage. It provides very cheap access to a lot of things that people like me, who live their lives in the cities, take for granted.

The member for Dobell (Mr Lee) made a number of very interesting points about the kinds of services which will be available on the Internet—not just the data, not just slow‐moving video and slow‐talking audio, but also full‐speed and very watchable television quality audio and video content. These are the sorts of things which technology is providing and which government has to consider.

The Internet is, for so many reasons, significant to Australia's prosperity within a global information economy. Business and consumers must be very confident that there is the right regulatory regime and that all Australians, regardless of age or inclination, can use the Internet safely and with confidence, particularly concerning restriction of access to certain types of material. I believe, as I am sure many other members contributing to this debate believe, that the Internet can and will be used for the conduct of more and more business.

The Attorney‐General is also acting on matters relating to the Internet, considering the establishment of an expert group. I understand that the Australian Taxation Office is also looking at the obvious matters of tax evasion and how existing laws may impact on, or miss, Internet transactions. I suspect that soon we may well see international treaties being negotiated which include aspects of how the Internet is impacting. There could be treaties between Australia and other countries to discuss how content generated in another nation and accessible here in Australia can, perhaps, be restricted. Those are matters which the government will be looking at, and this bill provides for the ABA to play a positive role in that discussion process.

I look back at the coalition's policy document released prior to the election, Australia Online. We stated our determination to continue to reform copyright laws so as to be responsive to the challenges of modern electronic technologies. We talked about censorship—there is certainly a great deal of public interest in that—and we talked about the gambling aspect of the Internet. The government is determined that, on that particular front, there should be a tough regulatory regime. Probity checks, the preclusion of criminal influence, the protection of the interests of players to make sure that there are no disreputable games, controls to stop minors gambling, measures to ensure that gambling products are fully auditable and that gambling taxes are levied, are all matters of importance. So, there are certainly some powerful agents at work in this debate and the future looks quite exciting. But the matters which the ABA must now look at will ensure that the future will not just be exciting and exhilarating, with all things possible, but will also include a safe regime for those who want to access the Internet.

The role of the Internet as a pick and choose, consumer oriented medium with power to the user and as a source of information and entertainment are all very important matters which this bill allows the ABA, on behalf of the government, to investigate fully. The Internet, as I said, is an important facet of the debate currently going on over cross‐media ownership. It may well prove to be the cheapest form of media access for those who want to become additional players and providers of information. All in all, there are many reasons for this place to support this bill and I certainly commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to support the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill 1996. I guess that the opposition is supporting the bill, but although in the speeches of the two previous speakers on behalf of the government we have heard a lot of well‐meaning statements, the actual statement in the second reading speech by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) contains none of that. All we are given here is a very rough outline from the minister, or the minister's office, indicating that he wants this power and that he intends to use it in some way or another in relation to these issues—including the issue of the Internet. Government speakers have spoken about some of the issues which concern them and which they would like to see taken up in the regulations. But there is nothing in the statement from the minister that indicates that any of those issues will be taken up.

BREAK.PARA: All that there is here is the provision of the power to the minister in the hope that something will be done. If the minister is going to respond to this debate from both sides of the chamber, maybe the minister or his representative could come in here and tell us what exactly the government is interested in doing with respect to this power.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Moreton (Mr Hardgrave) mentioned a number of important issues. He mentioned, for example, the fact that the ABA, the Australian Broadcasting Authority, has been hopelessly slow in terms of providing access to radio waves. It is only now, this year, after so much pain and angst over the years, that we are suddenly told that there are so many more available radio station positions.
—It is wonderful what a change of government does!

—No, it is not a question of a change of government; it is a question of the behaviour of the Australian Broadcasting Authority. I remember years ago that in order to get a single radio station for a particular ethnic community you had to have the biggest fight in Australia. Now we are told that, because of digital technology and so on, we could have had these radio stations years ago. The way in which this whole process of giving out licences takes place is now going to become very interesting, because some people have paid a lot of money for licences and now there is going to be a whole series of licences available which we were previously told were not even technically available.
—That is the new minister's doing.

—It is not the new minister's doing; it has to do with the fact that the ABA has finally caught up with technology. So I agree with the member for Moreton that the behaviour of the ABA in relation to that area of administration is not exactly such that we can be full of confidence. While I agree that the minister should have these new powers, I am interested to know what kind of directions the minister is going to give the ABA because, quite frankly, they are going to need some good directions. If the general direction is going to be, `Look, a consideration of issues with respect to the Internet,' some very broad question, we may not get the results that we want. It is very important in this matter that the minister specify the issues which the ABA is to consider when it is considering the regulatory regime. The minister ought to issue a statement saying, `These are the sorts of issues which we expect the ABA to consider in its consideration of this matter.'

BREAK.PARA: We know that in its own report, Investigation into the content of online services, dated 30 June 1996, the Australian Broadcasting Authority confirmed that most online information and entertainment services would not be covered by the current definition of broadcasting service. That is why we have got this bill. They have said that. So we are going to extend these provisions so that they do cover the online services. We are going to ask the ABA to look into the matter of what sorts of regulations should be put into place, especially in relation to the Internet. But we want to know how they are going to deal with some very serious issues—and the member for Moreton mentioned some of them.

We need to have specific directions from the minister in relation to these issues. We need to know, for example, what is going to happen with respect to the gambling on the Internet. What is going to happen with respect to copyright issues on the Internet, especially the protection of intellectual property of authors? If it is going to become a situation that every time you publish a book somebody can put it onto the Internet and anybody can access the book, what is going to happen to the poor authors? I think this is going to be a very serious issue in the future. The technology is running ahead of our considerations in terms of regulation in relation to this matter.

Then there is another question: what about material which is actually defamatory in a certain way or material which, for one reason or another, should be kept secret? What about material which belongs to the privacy of an individual? What happens if that material is put onto the Internet, especially if it is put onto the Internet in another country?

As an example of this, members of the state opposition in Victoria wanted information in relation to some business investments of the Kennett government. They put in an FOI request and the FOI request was rejected. As it turned out, the state opposition found the information on the Internet because the American company that was involved in the dealings had put it on the Internet. That is an interesting story, and one that benefited the Labor Party on that occasion. However, the reality is that this is not necessarily the kind of situation we want if there are going to be proper business dealings around the world.

Another matter which the member for Moreton did not mention—understandably, because it is a matter which does not directly concern him, although it certainly concerns me—is the question of putting racist and other material on the Internet, material which is intended to injure particular ethnic communities or particular groups of people. That is a very serious question. We know that there are extremist and fanatical groups which hate the Jewish community, the Arabic community, the Chinese community and many other communities. Those fanatical organisations are able to put material onto the Internet and make it available to other people. Will the regulatory regime be able to deal with those sorts of issues?

TALK.START.PARA: —It must.

—It must, the honourable member says, and I applaud him for that. This is a very serious question from the point of view of protecting our multicultural society and ensuring that we do not get around the laws which were put in place in relation to racial discrimination and racial vilification. It is very important that, when the minister responds to this bill, he tells us whether he is prepared to take up these issues in terms of the directions to be given to the ABA.

BREAK.PARA: There is no doubt that the mass expansion of telecommunications presents wonderful opportunities: opportunities for learning, opportunities for contacting people around the world, opportunities for understanding each other's cultures and each other's traditions. We can make the world a better place through these systems. But there are also dangers which can make it a difficult place.

In this regard, I mentioned the issues of racial and cultural discrimination, but there is also the issue of protection of children. It seems to me that it is going to be possible for some very disgusting material to be put on the Internet—material about the abuse of children; material which extends beyond the normal levels of pornography into violence against women, or violence against people generally, the promotion of horrible crimes, and that sort of thing.

It is very important that, whatever provisions are put into place, this kind of material be stopped. I am not sure how that is going to be done technologically, but if this regulatory regime which they are talking about is going to be a real regulatory regime, it has to focus on this issue as well.

I have mentioned a number of important issues that the regulatory regime has to deal with. Honourable members will probably mention others. The minister has asked for this power. The bill will provide him with the power. The bill will provide for the referral of these issues to the ABA. Let us get some answers now. What issues will be referred to the ABA? What specific directions is the minister going to give the ABA in relation to the regulations?

Also, I think we need to know something about the timetable that is going to be put into place. What is that timetable to be? Are we talking about years? Are we talking about some immediate provisions to be put in place quickly? The bill suggests that this is the case, that the minister wants to put in place some reasonably quick provisions. Let us get those provisions down. Let us learn from international experience, from what other countries are doing. Later on, we can then have a legislative provision, as has been promised, where we will debate the whole issue of on‐line services, the Internet and the like. We may perhaps have a separate act to cover all these questions.

In the meantime, if we are going to give that power to the ABA, let us give some directions from the minister to cover the concerns that have been put forward by honourable members. Let us put that into place as quickly as we can so that we can protect our community and we can be sure that the Internet is going to operate positively for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly, Jackie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, picture this, as Mark Bastable in the Australian writes:

SPEECH.PARA: Computer nerds need feel lonely no longer, thanks to Girlfriend Tracy, a mail‐order CD‐ROM that combines virtual reality and artificial intelligence to create an interactive `humanoid' companion, with whom one can spend many romantic evenings in the flickering light of the home computer.
Tuesday . . . The postie delivers Tracy, my virtual girlfriend, with whom—the disc's cover assures me—I am about to form a lifelong relationship.
I slip her into my computer and prepare to interact with her artificial intelligence.
She's not a bad looker, sitting on the sofa in jeans and a cut‐off top. She asks me the colour of my hair and eyes, which, amazingly, turn out to be the . . . colour . . . she really likes.
She speaks in a synthesised voice that sounds like a Swede sucking a lolly. I quite like her.
Wednesday . . . Tracy answers the door in a short skirt and a crisp blouse. Nice touch from the programmers. We talk about my family, by whom she seems fascinated.
She's not the brightest girl I have dated; but not the dumbest either. Her similarity to a Scandinavian au pair is reinforced by a tendency to be confused with my vocabulary.
The article goes on and it gets quite hysterical as he takes up a second lover from another CD‐ROM given to him by his weekend host. He writes:
. . . Virtual Valerie, a computer generated bikie babe who (he tells me) goes like a snake on skis.
I tell him that meaningless cybersex is OK, but I have something serious going.
He asks me how.
You wouldn't understand, I reply.

It goes on, with virtual Valerie ending up having an affair with his boss, who manages to get her meter going. With cyberspace the future in the entertainment industry is phenomenal. I think I have to defer to the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson), who always says, `I do not know what pornography is but I sure recognise it when I see it.' It is a very difficult line to draw. That has been left up to the ABA and I think that is a sensible place for it.

There have been cases recently where offensive material on neo‐Nazism—which is banned in Germany and, in fact, the CEO of Compuserve was up on charges there—was transmitted into Germany from Denmark. Subsequently, Germany has regulated to have a more appropriate mechanism for stopping that. Making the liability for information that goes over these transmissions the domain of service providers would very quickly put them out of business. They would have to be continuously applying legal skills in order to determine whether material infringes the rights of others, be it in copyright, pornography or financial matters.
There is also a question about the amount of information that can be tracked. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald highlights just what information people can gain from the Internet. It states:

. . . the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation bought from Harrods of London a list of 50,000 big‐spending account-holders for the purpose of direct mailing them with offers of holidays in sunny Queensland.

A Harrods executive had worked with the corporation to select a direct‐mailing list of relatively young big spenders from among the store's 300,000 account‐holders. Harrods was able to narrow down to the customers who had used Harrods to buy sports gear and travel and even to those who had an annual income of about $150,000.

Whether or not those Harrod's card‐holders knew this information had been processed and passed on to Queensland tourism promoters is not known, but many Australian card‐holders would be horrified if Grace Bros or David Jones did a similar deal.

The thing is that, on the Internet, the site generally leaves a cookie with your computer for ease of future connections. Now we have the technology of push servicing as well, where you can list matters that you are particularly interested in, which certainly gives a profile on you as a consumer. As services databases reach such proportions, certainly that information is going to become exceptionally valuable. It is going to raise serious issues of privacy and it raises a number of issues also for newspaper advertising. If, instead of buying the newspapers to flick through and read the entire newspaper, I simply want to download the business section and maybe the front page, where does that leave the advertisers? Where does it leave the paper industry in Australia? As the recent deal of PBL and Microsoft shows, they have recognised the future of this technology; they have recognised the big bucks involved. In fact, Telstra hope to gain 25 per cent of the multimedia market, which they estimate will be worth around $3 billion a year in Australia by the year 2000.

There are enormous issues that have to be faced sometime in the future. We certainly have to start doing it. The future will be having a black box next to your television or possibly even televisions with their own net computers installed, giving you access to any video, CD, entertainment, the Australian Stock Exchange and banking. That is another case for fraud, where a number of electronic equities and futures markets have made public offerings without prospectuses and have allowed people to offer unlicensed investment advice over the net. All of that needs to be tidied up and regulated. With the development of electronic commerce we need to provide adequate protection for investors in this area.

For those who are worried about their credit card details going over the Internet and what sort of database record about you can be kept, or what sort of access can be gained, that is a thing of the past. We now have Telstra moving in with Surelink, which is an electronic payment service which enables customers to buy goods and services without having to provide credit card or other personal details over the net at each purchase. You can arrange payments with services who are linked up to Surelink and your details stay with Telstra.

Certainly, in other countries there are credit providers who operate solely on the net. They are not linked up in this case with Westpac and Advance and other banking systems. So even credit on the net is becoming not a problem. Shopping is a reality. I think everyone has given the example of importing CDs into Australia. Brash's sell CDs for about $30, coming down to about $27 if you are buying three or four. There is CD Now, CD Connection and CD Universe in the United States, who will all get landed into Australia five CDs for as little as $22. That is up to $7 in savings on an item which is very easy to import into the country and escape the 22 per cent sales tax, which is too much of a headache for Customs. They do not consider that that revenue is worth the expensive and time consuming audit procedures necessary to catch that sort of business. But that example itself is becoming outdated. In the future you will be able to get quite good quality CD sounds and even video images down the net.

It is opening up very interesting things like telehealth for rural services, where you can visit a nurse's office or a person's quarters if you are sick in the bush, and via videoconferencing you can have specialist help from the city in terms of diagnostics, asking questions and looking at various things.

Those of you have been to any up-to-date dental surgery recently would have seen the fibre-optic links on the end of the drill bit, which will show you on a screen above you exactly what the dentist is doing to your teeth—for those of you who want to watch. Certainly, for rural industry, telehealth has dramatic implications, given the difficulty we have in locating doctors out in rural areas.
