Suddenly, we will be able to deliver to rural people state-of-the-art, up-to-date services from doctors in the city who are linked to universities and who are able to access conferences and professional updating activities that occur in the cities.
Picture this:

Twas the week before Christmas, and the employees of XYZ Corp. were logging off a successful year with holiday parties at headquarters in New York. Meanwhile, inside their darkened offices, not a creature was stirring, not even a computer mouse—or so they thought. Unbeknownst to the merrymakers, a team of professional hackers in Texas was preparing to invade XYZ's systems from 2,500 km. away.

Operation Nutcracker, as we'll call it, spanned two nights. By the time the sun started to scroll over San Antonio on the second day, the hackers had penetrated seven of XYZ's computers. They'd invaded a subsidiary near Washington, D.C., and the corporate tax division in Manhattan. They'd gained "route access" on five systems, meaning that they'd seized the full powers enjoyed by XYZ's systems administrators. Most alarmingly, they'd invaded XYZ's electronic heart—
which was basically only accessed by its technology department, and:
The operation was never detected.

That comes from a recent Time magazine article entitled, `Who's Reading Your E‐mail?'. Hacking, whether for sport, for corporate espionage or for just sheer vandalism, has certainly been a problem in the United States and there are a number of groups looking to target it and find ways of firewalling industry. It is almost like the arms race or star wars. If CEOs do not believe it is a problem, then sooner or later they are going to get whacked, as the article recommends. It is a major headache for the future of Australia. It is something that we cannot ignore and this bill goes some way to looking at it.

The comment has been made, `It is not specific enough.' How do you get specific with such a fluid arrangement? This technology is developing at an enormous rate of knots. Almost by tomorrow we may have the technology to put various bars on incoming information or to exclude various source sites as far away as the Cayman Islands.

It is very important, coming up to the end of the financial year, that we also look at tax evasion. It is something that I have been seriously concerned about since I entered this parliament. Industry in Australia is increasingly becoming service based. We rely a lot on employment in the services industry. We rely a lot on taxing things in the services area, and services is one of the key things that can easily be transmitted down a telephone line, be it legal services, architectural services, music, entertainment, accommodation booking, travel arrangements or shopping. Anything can be done over a telephone line. It means that you do not have to have a shopfront, you do not have to have a fixed place of address, and you certainly can be operating offshore. It opens up a worldwide market to you.

That has enormous implications for our tax regime and it certainly does mean that we are going to have to continue to regulate, to close, all the loopholes that are available in this technology. For those of you who have not read it I recommend very strongly The clever country? Australia's digital future, written by Daniel Petre and David Harrington, formerly of Microsoft.

Microsoft is a leader in this area. Traditionally, in the whole area of computer programming it has seen where industry is going and has always kept ahead of it. Certainly, it has been quick to capitalise on new ideas and new trends and has moved with them. I think its move into media with PBL is another indication of its vision. That is something governments ignore at their peril. People can be very selective about what news they wish to hear with push technology.

The opportunity for a very open and frank editorial discussion of our political system is lost. Even without editors, The Clever Country? makes a number of references in terms of Beijing and Tiananmen Square in 1989, where Chinese students connected to the Internet were giving real time reports and pleas for help before many of the international news crews had broadcast them. Similarly, Internet users were amongst the first to hear Boris Yeltsin speaking to crowds from a tank and then barricading himself in the parliament buildings when Latvia declared its independence. There was also Gorbachev returning from house arrest in the Crimea and so on. All of these events were broadcast first on the Internet: real time and real life without the interference of editorial or journalist interpretation. That is the reality of the future of news reviews, not only in Australia but across the world.

The bill has serious implications. It also makes some very pertinent remarks about digital democracy. What implications does that sort of technology have for democracy? Government always has to be aware of trends in those areas and must move to respond to community concerns.

There have been a number of concerns expressed from Internet service providers in my area about Big Pond. If you are linked up with anyone but Big Pond, your screen immediately fills with a number of messages from other Internet service providers that are concerned about market share with Telstra and what that holds for them in the future. Although the ACCC has carriage of that, now having the ABA also looking at the regulation of what goes on‐line is important as well. I am linked up to Penrith Netcom in my area as a local service provider. I think I was one of the first to bring the laptop technology into parliament and, as soon as I can afford the cable, I will also be linked up on my mobile phone. So I will not be far away.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will lead us all up there.

—That is the key thing as well; a lot of this technology is getting cheaper all the time. I might baulk at the moment at paying $700 for a cable, but quite shortly that will get right down and be within my reach and the reach of most other users as well. It is not pie in the sky that this is going to be in everyone's home, that it is going to be user‐ friendly for everyone. Australians, more than anyone else in the world, have adapted very quickly to ATMs and EFTPOS transactions. We have seen a 40 per cent increase per annum in EFTPOS transactions in Australia. We like that ease and that style of financial management and shopping. The future is there with the Internet service providers and the content producers as well. It will fulfil all of those expectations and probably go beyond them.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill goes some way to looking at the necessary regulation of all this—commerce, pornography, social values, entertainment, financial transactions, telehealth, gambling, copyright, news, criminal offences and just doing ordinary business. It will also be used in areas around the home. It is a phenomenal and very exciting area. Instead of resisting change and hoping and thinking that it will not have the impact that it will have in the next five years, we should get on the bus and get with technology. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALKER.NAME: Mr WARWICK SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)

TALK.START.PARA: —If everyone has finished, I take the opportunity to sum up. Firstly, I thank honourable members for their contribution. I regret that I was unable to hear some of them. I would compliment the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) for a very well researched and thoughtful contribution to what is a very important debate that has been recognised by every speaker here this morning. I am pleased that the opposition will be supporting the measures in the bill also, and we thank the opposition and the member for Dobell (Mr Lee), who spoke about that.

SPEECH.PARA: The fundamental point to recognise is that the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill 1996 will enable the minister to direct the ABA—the Australian Broadcasting Authority—to conduct an investigation into any matter within the communications power under paragraph 51(v) of the constitution. In particular, the minister would be empowered to direct the ABA to conduct an investigation into a matter relating to the future regulation or operation of communications services, such as on‐line information and entertainment services, that so many people have been talking about this morning.

An important purpose of the amendment is, therefore, to ensure that the minister's power to conduct those investigations can extend to future regulatory arrangements and policy directions in respect of on‐line services. The reason for this was that the current definition of broadcasting services in section 6 of the act excludes services that make programs available on demand on a point‐to‐point basis, including dial‐up services. In a report to the minister entitled `Investigation into the content of online services', dated 30 June 1996, the ABA confirmed that most on‐line information and entertainment services would not be covered by the current definition of broadcast services.

What is proposed in this legislation is to get around that problem to give a legislative base for the minister to be able to refer to the ABA a reference to look at future aspects of on‐line services, to go into the marketplace to conduct detailed consultations with the industry and others. There has been a deal of concern expressed by all members today. This is an interim measure, as was outlined in the second reading speech which the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) did on my behalf, to enable us to move quickly in this area to address some of the concerns that we obviously have.

This matter coming before the government is not new. Indeed, I can recall drawing up terms of reference when we were proposing legislation in 1991 about looking at the content of services. At that stage, a Senate committee was established, so we have been grappling with these issues.

BREAK.PARA: The point that has been ably made by the member for Lindsay is that these services and the technology and the digital Australia that is arriving mean that it is happening ever more quickly. Therefore, in public policy terms, governments are going to be required to also move quickly.

Several members made some points. The honourable member for Dobell did identify the legitimate public concerns with regard to objectionable content on the Internet and particularly in regard to the protection of children. He also pointed to the difficulties in effective regulation of on‐line services. Obviously, we agree with him on that. As I have mentioned, the amendment in the bill is a starting point and an interim step to enable us to proceed as quickly as possible.

We are committed to a wide‐ranging industry consultation on a comprehensive regulatory scheme. The intention of the proposed amendment to section 171 of the Broadcasting Services Act is to allow the ABA to consult with the on‐line services industry on the development of appropriate codes of practice and other relevant matters to facilitate a smooth transition to the new regulatory framework.

The developments of the codes of practice are an essential feature of what we are proposing. We would hope that all the matters that have been raised, for example, by the member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), are of concern. I would assure him that the codes of practice and the issues that will be spelled out will include such matters as racial vilification. The directions will spell out those matters that would be put into the code.

The broader point made by the member for Lindsay about the examples that she quoted and the importance of the on‐line industry is recognised. This is a growth industry. It has huge economic benefits for those involved. It also carries with it major social issues that we need to be dealing with, such as those affecting children and content and so on. All of those matters need to be considered. There is constitutional power for the Commonwealth to be involved and this amendment gives effect to the minister being able to refer to an expert body to start that broad‐based community consultation.

There was one other matter raised by the member for Dobell about the current status of the ABA's investigation into the uses of the sixth channel in Sydney and Melbourne. I understand that the ABA has reported to the minister. The minister is considering those issues and in due course we will be making a response to that report.

I do thank honourable members. This is an important matter. It is recognised as such by the government and that is why we are proposing this legislative amendment. We are delighted that the opposition has seen fit to participate positively in the debate and support the legislation. With those few words I have pleasure in concluding the summing up and commending the bill to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 2 June.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this bill is to make a number of amendments to enhance the Fisheries Administration Act 1991, the Fisheries Management Act 1991 and the Torres Strait Fisheries Act 1984. The Fisheries Administration Act and the Fisheries Management Act came into effect in February 1992 and the proposed amendments seek to correct minor anomalies in them that have been identified over the last four years, streamline their administration and generally improve the efficiency of fisheries management.

With regard to the Fisheries Administration Act, a number of the proposed amendments seek to clarify the wording to put beyond doubt the original intention about the functions of the Australian Fisheries Management Authority. In particular, the amendments make it explicit that AFMA is not only to devise but also to manage and carry out adjustment, restructuring, exploratory and feasibility fishing programs. Secondly, AFMA is to have the function of providing expertise to and exchanging information with states and territories as well as overseas bodies having functions similar to AFMA.

Another amendment provides for the maximum period for which a person can serve consecutive terms as a director of AFMA to be expressed in years instead of as a number of terms. A number of further amendments specify arrangements under which subcommittees to fisheries management advisory committees may be established and operate. A minor consequential amendment is also made to the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 to enable that tribunal to determine travelling allowances payable to management authority committee and subcommittee members.

In both the Fisheries Administration Act and the Fisheries Management Act, some definitions are clarified and some new definitions are added. Both acts have also been amended to require the minister and AFMA to act in a manner consistent with the precautionary principle as defined in the intergovernmental agreement on the environment. The precautionary principle provides that where there are threats of serious or irreversible environmental damage the lack of full scientific certainty should not be used as a reason for postponing measures to prevent environmental degradation. Amendments to both acts also require the minister and AFMA to have particular regard to the impact of fishing activities on the long-term sustainability of the marine environment.

As far as the Fisheries Management Act is concerned, one of the most significant amendments gives effect to the government's policy, announced before the last election, to provide greater security of long‐term access to fisheries. The purpose of this amendment is to protect the fishing industry against changes in government or administrative policy which the revocation of management plans might otherwise entail. This will give greater security of investment to both fishing operators and financiers.

Under the amendments, where a management plan for a fishery is revoked, any subsequent plan that covers all or part of that fishery must provide that holders of statutory fishing rights at the time of the revocation will have first option on a proportional basis to similar rights granted under the subsequent plan.

A further amendment requires plans of management to provide for the incidental catch of non‐target commercial and other species to be kept to a minimum. Further amendments to the Fisheries Management Act require AFMA to determine plans of management for all fisheries and to maintain a register of persons and organisations who are to be notified of draft plans of management. If AFMA is of the view that a plan of management for a particular fishery is not warranted, then it may make a determination accordingly, including its reasons. Notice of a determination must be given to persons and organisations on the register and published in the Gazette.

Other amendments to the management act seek to improve arrangements for the registration of interests and dealings in statutory fishing rights and administrative arrangements in respect of fisheries which are managed by a fisheries joint authority under Commonwealth law.

Fisheries joint authorities provide one type of arrangement for achieving cooperation between the Commonwealth, the states and the Northern Territory in the management of fisheries. Joint authorities are bodies consisting of Commonwealth and state or territory ministers responsible for fisheries. As things stand, the ministers in a joint authority may delegate powers to AFMA but AFMA has no intrinsic power in the management of joint authority fisheries.

The philosophy of the management act is to divorce the Commonwealth ministers from day‐to‐day management decisions and, to this end, the primary function of the minister in relation to Commonwealth fisheries is to accept plans of management determined by AFMA. This is not the case with joint authority fisheries and, after due consultation with the states, the amendments seek to rectify this anomaly.

The bill therefore amends the management act to create the same relationship between AFMA and joint authorities as it has with the Commonwealth ministers in respect of other Commonwealth managed fisheries.

The remaining amendments to the Fisheries Management Act focus on various enforcement, penalty and related provisions, a number of which arise from recommendations made in the 1993 report entitled, Fisheries reviewed, by the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.

One of the amendments relates to the powers of officers to enter land or premises specified in a fish receiver permit. Currently, an officer may enter such premises only with the consent of the holder of the fish receiver permit or under a warrant. It is proposed to amend the act to enable officers to enter premises subject to a fish receiver permit for monitoring purposes at any time without the requirement for either consent or warrant, and to secure a property pending the obtaining of a warrant. However, the power to seize property or documents will still be conditional on the officer having a warrant.

In other circumstances where a warrant is required for a search to be conducted, there has been criticism that the obtaining of warrants under section 85 of the management act is cumbersome compared to obtaining warrants under the crimes act of 1914. The bill amends the act so that it reflects the Crimes Act provision. Section 95 provides for various offences which, with the exception of offences relating to foreign boats, are dealt with summarily and attract maximum fines of $10,000. This level of penalty is inadequate when the commission of single offences can net the offender in excess of $100,000.

Amendments to section 95 increase the level of penalties. Those currently at $10,000 will go to $25,000, those currently at $5,000 to $12,500 and those currently at $2,000 to $5,000. Maximum fines applicable to certain offences involving the use of foreign boats are set at $50,000 and there is no intention to raise these penalties. However, in line with Commonwealth criminal law policy, as expressed in the Crimes Act, opportunity is taken to express all penalties as penalty units, currently with the value of $100 per unit. This enables a change to the unit value in the Crimes Act to have effect in all Commonwealth legislation in which penalties are expressed in these units.

The Torres Strait Fisheries Act, being of earlier origin, lacks some of the features included in the administration and management act. It is proposed to amend the Torres Strait act to give the Torres Strait Protected Zone Joint Authority one of the powers considered central to modern fisheries management, namely, the power to make management plans. These amendments envisage the making of management plans for Torres Strait fisheries based on units of fishing capacity, which could be based on inputs or outputs. The amendment provisions are in line with Commonwealth government policy that aims to eventually bring all Commonwealth controlled fisheries under arrangements based on a management plan.
I commend the bill to honourable members and present three copies of the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does not intend to oppose the major elements of the bill, before the Main Committee today, the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. Australia's fishing industry is basically governed by three acts—the Fisheries Administration Act 1991, the Fisheries Management Act 1991 and the Torres Strait Fisheries Act 1994. The legislation before us today, as has been outlined by the minister, corrects anomalies that have been identified over the passage of the past five years. I think that is a very worthwhile undertaking as far as the government is concerned. It streamlines the operation of the administration of the Australian fishing industry and has the general objective of improving the efficiency of fisheries management in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: It is pleasing to see that the legislation has the broad industry support which has been achieved after a process of consultation with the industry. One would hope that the lessons that have been learned in the agricultural portfolio would be translated into the general industry portfolio, because in other areas, for example as far as the bounty legislation is concerned, there has been very little consultation when the government made its decisions to curtail the bounties in those manufacturing industries that are affected by that legislation. At least it is pleasing to see here that the government is prepared to consult with the industry and that legislation that it brings before the parliament has some broad industry support.

I want to comment on the two main acts that govern Australia's fishing operations and the key amendments that are being proposed in this legislation. As far as the fisheries administration act is concerned, this act basically sets out the role of the Australian Fisheries Management Authority and the amendments that are before the Main Committee today further clarify that role. That particular authority has the duty now to manage and execute the adjustment restructuring, exploration and feasibility of fishing programs in this country. An additional function has been added in that the authority must now liaise more intently with the state administering authorities as far as the exchange of information is concerned and, of course, that function of liaison with overseas fishing bodies is similarly important.

As far as the Fisheries Management Act is concerned, a key amendment—as the minister has mentioned—relates to the security and long‐term access to fisheries by people who participate in this industry. The minister made the point that the purpose of the amendment is to protect the fishing industry against changes in government or administrative policy which the revocation of management plans might otherwise entail.

This will give greater security of investment to both fishing operators and financiers. Once again it is an interesting contrast, isn't it, with the attitude of the government in this legislation relating to primary industry and its attitude to the bounty legislation which we debated on the main floor of the House yesterday? There particular commitments were given to manufacturers or book publishers and people manufacturing computers, machine tools and robots—

TALK.START.PARA: —And shipbuilding.

—And shipbuilding, as the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams) has a deep interest in that industry. Specific promises were given and broken. Of course, on the back of those promises, those people engaged in those industries made their investment decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Here today on the floor of the Main Committee, the government is telling us that it is very important to provide a secure framework in which people can operate within an industry and make investment decisions. Get your act together, I say to people on the other side. Get some consistency in the way you handle primary industries and value‐adding industries associated with primary production and manufacturing industries generally.

People understate the importance of this industry to the national economy and to our export performance. It ranks fifth among Australia's most valuable agricultural industries. Many people would not appreciate that fact. It ranks after wool, meat, dairying and wheat production as a very important agricultural pursuit. The growth value of fisheries production in Australia in 1995‐1996 was $1.36 billion.An interesting statistic also is that exports in 1995‐1996 accounted for over 81 per cent of that production value. This is not an insignificant industry in the context of Australia's overall export performance and export effort.

The major destinations of those exports are Japan, Hong Kong and Taiwan. There is considerable scope for the expansion of markets in those countries and further development of value added production, projecting into other Asian markets which demand the output of our production.

I had the great fortune last night to sample some of the products of Australia's great seafood industry at a function put on by none other than the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams), as he periodically does. He ships up that great smoked salmon from Tasmania. He tells us on all on every occasion—he drums this into us—it is absolutely killing them on overseas markets. I will speak a little bit more about the threats to that particular industry because I know the honourable member for Lyons has had a deep and abiding interest in those issues. He has fought the hard fight on the floor of the parliament and out in the general community to protect salmon production in the state of Tasmania and the great export potential that we have with that product.

Another important characteristic we ought to note about this industry is that it is regionally based. It is a great creator of direct and value added employment in regional areas. Australia has a large coastline. Our fishing zone is the third largest in the world and the bulk of our population is located in the coastal zone, especially in coastal cities and towns along the eastern seaboard of Australia. We need careful maintenance and sustainability of this industry because that is critical to the economic existence and viability of many coastal towns. It is the key, I believe, to the generation of new job income and wealth in regional areas.

Many regional communities, including my own, recognise the potential of this industry. In my electorate of Corio, Cheetham is involved in a large aquaculture development on the shores of Corio Bay. They have expressed to me that they see this industry as having great potential for growth and export. I also have in my electorate Australian Foods, a significant employer, value added producer and exporter in Geelong. These companies are very keen to develop the electorate's capacity as far as this industry is concerned.

BREAK.PARA: We welcome the decision that was made by the Victorian government recently to abandon the relocation of the Coode Island chemicals complex to Point Lillias, because it would have threatened directly the expansion of Cheetham in the aquaculture area. That expansion offers far greater capacity to generate employment and wealth in the Geelong region than the location of a chemicals dump at Point Lillias would ever do. This is an industry that needs strategic planning to realise its potential, because it does have finite stocks for harvest and they have to be protected and managed very carefully, in the interests not only of the people who make their living from the industry but also of the nation.

I mention that particular point because, at this point in the political cycle, we have a government that lacks vision as far as the development of any concrete planning in industries is concerned. We have a hapless minister for the manufacturing industry at the moment and we have a Prime Minister who lacks leadership in directing his industry minister in many of those areas. But at least it is pleasing to see the government tightening up some legislation here in the primary industry area and, of course, developing this industry and securing it in the long term.

Like many other industries in agriculture, it has opportunities for expansion and development but it also has problems that naturally threaten and constrict that development. One fundamental issue of concern is developing a management regime that sustains the fisheries that underpin the industry. Fish stocks in many areas are over‐exploited, and we have over‐capacity and over‐capitalisation in the fishing fleet, which has put pressure on the fishers to seek greater returns by over‐fishing the existing stocks.

A very important point that we need to understand about this particular industry is that it draws its sustenance from existing stocks, and those stocks need to be protected and developed if this industry is to be developed. It is not like other agricultural industries, in the sense that others can go out and plant more acres of wheat or grain—or onions, as I have been known to do in the not too distant past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very good onions, too!

—They are. The honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams) and I had the debate about the quality of Western District onions as opposed to Tasmanian onions. I must say that their salmon is better than we would produce in our region; but, of course, our onions are better than the member for Lyons could produce.

BREAK.PARA: Getting off onions and back to the issue of fish, it is very important to note that we need strategic planning in the management of this resource, if it is to grow and develop. There are significant quarantine issues that relate to this particular industry. Of course, the fisheries are under threat from diseases that can be imported to this country. I am sure the honourable member for Lyons will have more to say in his speech to the Main Committee on that particular aspect.

There are also environmental factors that this industry has to consider: because of the way in which untrammelled fishing has been conducted in some fisheries around this nation, we have seen many species endangered. As far as the total industry is concerned, we look at aquaculture as having potential for development, but there are considerable pollution problems that are associated with expanding aquaculture production, because it is usually done in very environmentally sensitive coastal areas where land space is a priority and where very fragile environments exist. It is not an industry without opportunity and potential for growth, but it must critically address the problems that present themselves.

Before I close I would like to make some comments on aquaculture and the future of the industry, because this particular piece of legislation does tighten things up in this area. Geelong has recognised the potential of aquaculture. As a local community we have developed a strategic plan for the development of the industry in our area. I do welcome the decision that was made by the Victorian government not to locate a chemicals dump at Point Lillias because that chemicals dump would have directly threatened the expansion of Cheetham and other aquaculture producers in the region and certainly would have thwarted our attempts to develop in the environs of Avalon Airport a clean, green zone—a marketing advantage for which we can project our community and what we have to offer into overseas markets, particularly in Asia.

We have a plan afoot in the Geelong region to develop Avalon Airport as a dedicated airfreight facility for the export of perishable products, including products that are the output of this particular industry. If we were to get that project off the ground, get the jumbos flying directly into Asian markets—particularly in Japan and Hong Kong and Kuala Lumpur—on a very regular basis, then aquaculture producers not only in the Victorian coastal area and, of course, Corio Bay but also in the great state of Tasmania would come on board and ship their produce out through that facility. I know that because I have talked to them and they have indicated that that is what they want to do. What they need is security of supply and security as far as transporting and transhipment into the major markets of this industry.

So, in conclusion, I reiterate the fact that the opposition will not be opposing the major elements of this legislation. It does tidy up those anomalies in the legislation which have developed over four years. I guess at the end of the day it is a worthwhile exercise to tighten up the legislation and improve it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I rise today to speak on a topic of great concern to me, the Fisheries Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. We have just heard the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) and my colleague in the chamber, the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), who shares some great fishing ports with me through Forster—I have Port Stephens in my electorate; we share Forster and he goes further north to Port Macquarie—would agree after looking at and observing our fishing industry, that this week we have seen great flip‐flops with the opposition backflipping, looking worse than a mullet out of water on the decks of a boat.

SPEECH.PARA: But going back to the main aspect, the Fisheries Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 details amendments to the Fisheries Amendment Act 1991, the Fisheries Management Act 1991 and the Torres Strait Fisheries Act 1984. A sign of good government is one that evolves legislation to keep up with the requirements of best practice and good management of a situation, and this bill is a classic example of that.

The fisheries resource is one that is owned by all Australians but, unfortunately, it is not exclusively Australian as the fish that are coming in to be fished through this area of Australia are highly migratory. So, with the advent of the Fisheries Administration Act 1991, AFMA was established.

It is important to note that AFMA had three corporate goals which were laid out in their annual report. The first goal was fisheries management: to develop and implement fisheries management programs which would result in the conservation and sustainable use of all fisheries within its control, including the recovery of depleted fisheries, and to develop and implement fisheries management programs which would encourage the efficient exploitation of fisheries resources. The second goal, in communication, was to increase the level of awareness of fisheries resource issues within the broader community, with particular emphasis on the fishing industry and other users of marine resources.

The third goal relates to policy development and efficient administration to improve the efficiency, effectiveness, focus and balance of fisheries management, and to actively participate in the development of fisheries policy. Those goals are admirable and the bill goes a long way to maintaining those goals. What it has done, in essence, is start to take the monkey off the back of the bureaucracy.

One of the greatest stories that one can see or read is that of the joy of a parent, male or female, taking their children fishing—whether that is sitting on a riverbank, on the beach, on the rocks—and casting the line out to catch some fish. If, in Australia, we do not look at our fisheries management and observe one of the essential rules, which is sustainability, then I am afraid that that pleasure may soon disappear from the horizon. It has disappeared in many other countries throughout the world, through pollution, overexploitation of fisheries and depletion of stocks.

The proposed amendments to these administration and management acts seek to correct minor anomalies that have been identified in the acts over the last four years, streamline administration and generally improve the efficiency of fisheries management. It is very heartening to see that one of the most significant parts of this bill gives effect to the government reviving the heartland policy announced before the last election to amend Commonwealth fisheries legislation. In reviving the heartland policy, this government promised to amend Commonwealth fisheries legislation to provide secure long‐term access rights for operators licensed to fish in fisheries managed by the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, and, where a fisheries management plan is amended or revoked by AFMA, ensure that the holders of the statutory fishing rights or permits under previous plans are given first call on the issue of rights and permits under the new plan.

This is about equity and fairness for people who invest all that they have. The life of a fisherman is not easy. It is not the usual day that they go out there and the wind is down, and the seas are idyllic with a low‐rolling swell. Most of the time the weather conditions on the east coast of Australia, as my colleague the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) would agree, are rather horrendous. The average wind speed is in excess of 10 to 15 knots, which makes life out there not so comfortable.

When we are asking people to invest in better boats, and when we are asking people to put forward more money and invest in their industry, for their security, their livelihood and their children's future, the one thing that they need is resource security. Resource security is not only about the fish stocks but it is also about the ability to be able to fish that licence to its maximum, to be able to fish that licence without fear of closing down and without an alternative plan put to them.

This government is about fairness. It is about equity. As I said, we have seen that situation evolve here. As the minister said in his second reading speech, one of the most significant amendments to the Fisheries Management Act gives effect to the government's policy announced before the last election to provide greater security for long‐term access to fisheries—long‐term access and security are key words. They are words upon which people can build and develop.

BREAK.PARA: A lot that is contained in this bill before the House today is in the Commonwealth fisheries review put up by the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure in December 1993. It is very interesting reading. Whilst all reports are put together with the best intentions, sometimes peculiar interests can take off, or there can be misinterpretations or listening to the loudest lobby group. But what has been extracted from that report is some key critical elements to provide an ongoing fisheries management policy.

I have been involved, through the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Primary Industries, Resources and Rural and Regional Affairs, in a report that was tabled on Monday of this week entitled Managing Commonwealth fisheries: the last frontier. The report provides for a whole series of recommendations for the greater management of fisheries and resource security in Australia, and it presents some very interesting reading. One aspect in the report is that of game fishing. In Australia at the moment it is legal to capture and take to market a species called striped marlin. Unfortunately, striped marlin do not have the intelligence levels to be able to determine between the bait for black marlin or blue marlin, which are banned species.

They do not have the ability to discriminate, and neither do other billfish species such as spearfish, sailfish or broadbill. Whilst there is a market for striped marlin, the recommendation in the report by the committee was to exclude black and blue marlin. In a dissenting report which I put with that report, I called for the banning of all billfish being taken by commercial means.

As I said, long‐lining with hooks and baits that are set to catch striped marlin do not discriminate between black and blue billfish and therefore they come on board. They are not allowed to take those fish to market and they are not allowed to have them on board, so there is nothing worse than having to kill off a fish and then dump it in the ocean since the keeping of those species on board is illegal—it is an offence.

With the recommendation that I put forward that extends the committee's recommendation to ban all billfishing, fishermen will be able to go back to the types of hooks which would in general, not at all times but in general, exclude the capture of billfish because of their inability to set in the jaws and mouth region. The only time they will be captured is if the hook goes down into the gullet or the stomach and then it is an internal hook‐up.

Fisheries bring a lot of money to Australia. In past years we have always thought of Cairns as the game fishing capital of Australia, or the marlin capital of Australia. But, whilst Cairns may catch the largest marlin, in reality most marlin are caught off Sydney, through Port Stephens and up to Forster. My colleague the member for Lyons (Mr Adams), whose keen interest in fishing has been noted throughout the electorate, also made that comment.

To give you an example, in the recent Port Stephens game fishing competition, over the last weekend in February and the first weekend in March, there were 1,032 marlin tagged and released in a four‐day period. Whilst there are hundreds of marlin caught, tagged and released in the Great Barrier Reef area, particularly around Cairns, this was in a single four-day period. If you extrapolate that through the whole of the season I think you would be looking at over 2,000 marlin being tagged and released just off the Port Stephens area.

That says one thing—it says the stock is there and it is available. But without careful management plans, without thinking of the long‐term future security, they may disappear. We have been through cycles where we have seen the fish come and we have seen the fish go. Indeed, I have not seen the fishing as exciting as it was in this season for at least the last seven years. Some will say it has to do with the El Nino effect or other things. I prefer to put it down to the fisheries starting to recover a bit and so we are seeing more fish.

These fish in general were small fish, less than 120 kilograms, with the majority of those tagged less than 60 kilograms. That says that this is the juvenile run area as they come down towards Bermagui and then perhaps turn across to New Zealand, coming back up and starting the next cycle of their life off the spawning grounds, which includes Area E off the north Queensland coast.

One of the recommendations of that report is to ban long-line fishing for billfish in area E. I think that is a very wise recommendation and one that I will be urging the minister to take up because that is a major spawning ground for these fish as the fish do their cyclic run down the east coast of Australia, across towards New Zealand and then back up to spawn in the area known as Area E.

That, amazingly, was the recommendation by ETUMAC back in the early 1990s at which time, initially, all fishing was banned in Area E. But AFMA, for scientific reasons, looked at the fisheries and allowed fishers there to take the species of striped marlin from that area.

As I said, marlin do not have the ability to determine whether a bait is meant for them or not. Therefore, the by-catch of black and blue marlin in those areas, and other species of billfish, has been quite high. The records are not known because the fish are dumped over the side and nobody is going to tell you they have just knocked off 300 or 400 unwanted marlin in that area.

The other thing that is impressive about the report was the level of concern and consideration for the management of fisheries to include all interested members and groups involved in the fishery. This Fisheries Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 has increased the powers of AFMA to conduct and assemble subcommittees, as needed, and to abolish those subcommittees as needed to basically improve the management of the advisory committees and to determine how a subcommittee will perform its functions under that management role.

The other thing that is impressive about the report is the level of concern and consideration for the management of fisheries to include all interested members and groups involved in the fishery. In this Fisheries Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 it has increased the powers of AFMA to conduct and assemble subcommittees, as needed, and to abolish those subcommittees as needed to basically improve the management of the advisory committees and to determine how a subcommittee will perform its functions under that management role.

As with all subcommittees they will attract a large range of people and people of very high calibre. One of the unfortunate things when people come together to work on the future direction of their industry is that, other than certain people, they have been excluded from travelling allowances to attend and work on that. One of the things that this bill does is allow for members of the committees and subcommittees, properly convened, to be able to claim the correct travelling allowance as nominated by the tribunal. But it must be, as I said, for a validly convened subcommittee meeting. The last thing we would want to see is people jetsetting off around the country, in essence on a junket, chewing up the dollars of the fisheries. There is a cost recovery basis on the management of AFMA and those dollars should not be spent on travel instead of on management or, indeed, on fisheries research.

One of the areas that has particularly pleased me, as a keen fisherman, is the increase in penalties for illegal fishing operations. Whilst the bill in essence serves to turn dollar figures into penalty units, there have been some very pleasing increases in penalty units. One of those is in the provisions for the ban on driftnet fishing. We, I am sure, could all look and see some of the examples photographically displayed or remember back to the TV exposes on the driftnet fishing where we saw dolphins, whales, sharks and other unwanted species captured in these driftnets—driftnets that at times would break lose from their buoys and continue to do what they were intended to do, which is drift and become a total death hole for fish because the filament that is provided in those nets unfortunately does not break down that easily. A lot of these nets have been recovered in trawls and by long-lines as they have drifted along with the currents and run over the top of the lines or into the nets.

But increasing the values of penalties on things such as taking certain fish without specific permits from $5,000 to $12,500 is to be applauded. Taking of fish or unlawfully receiving fish or, particularly, using foreign boats for recreational fishing in the Australian fisheries zone, has also had its penalty increased from $5,000 to $12,500. The increasing of the maximum penalties from $5,000 to $10,000 or effectively 250 penalty units of $25,000 for unlawful commercial fishing in the Australian fishing zone and unlawfully removing fish from traps in the Australian fishing zone is to be applauded.

As I have said, this bill is about the long-term security of Australia's fisheries. Fish such as tuna that do not necessarily start their life cycle here but further up in the Pacific rim come through here and Australia must take a positive step forward in working in conjunction with outside groups such as Forum Fisheries Agencies which are based in Honiara. I had the pleasure of visiting them last October and reviewing their areas of operation. It showed me that the management of fisheries is taking on a broader perspective to provide for a long-term future and security.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What would be the cost to revenue of excluding education expenses from the Actual Means Test of Austudy.
(2) How are Austudy figures for both secondary and tertiary students calculated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Austudy (with expenditure of about $1.5 billion a year) is intended to assist in meeting the education costs for low income families. The Austudy Actual Means Test is intended to prevent wealthy families with the ability to minimise taxable income from circumventing the Austudy income and assets tests. The Actual Means Test allows comparison of the means of Pay As You Earn families with those of families having financial arrangements where taxable income may not be a good indicator of financial need for Commonwealth assistance.

Austudy is not intended to cover the total costs of education. The basic principle of the student assistance program is that families are responsible for the costs of educating their children. Austudy is simply a contribution for those families who are so financially disadvantaged that their children are at risk of not being able to undertake education without Commonwealth support.

Any amendment to the Austudy Actual Means Test which did not require an applicant to include education expenditure estimates as part of a family's actual means would be likely to have a substantial cost.

An exercise conducted last year demonstrated that of 11,209 applicants assessed as ineligible under the Actual Means Test between January and April 1996 (as at the end of April 1996), 7,425 applicants or about 66 per cent of ineligible clients would have become eligible for assistance if education costs had been excluded from a family's actual means. The cost to revenue if these figures were extrapolated on an annual basis was calculated at $28,528,555. A similar assessment has not been made for 1997 and it would be excessively costly to do so.

The inclusion of education costs as part of a family's actual means needs to be understood in the context of the overall student assistance scheme. Of an estimated 540,000 people expected to apply for Austudy in 1997, fewer than one‐quarter are expected to be assessed under the Actual Means Test. Even in these cases, most applicants who are assessed under the Actual Means Test are expected to be eligible for full or partial assistance in 1997.

(2) The Education and Student Assistance System (ESAS) computer program calculates, processes and stores all essential data for the payment of Austudy assistance to secondary and tertiary students. Every application for Austudy is registered in ESAS. ESAS calculates the entitlement of a student to Austudy assistance from information provided by the applicant in the Austudy application form. Such information includes income data of the student, parents or partner, the age of the student, whether the student qualifies for the at home or away from home rate, enrolment details, other dependents in the family, and any other relevant information which may affect a student's eligibility for Austudy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 27 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was the occurrence of fire blight discovered in Victoria.
(4) Who discovered the outbreak and what drew his or her attention to it.
(5) How large is the area of the outbreak.
(6) Is the disease transmitted by spores; if not, how.
(7) Is the fire blight in Melbourne the same as the strain that virtually wiped out pear production in New Zealand.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 2 May 1997, AQIS was informed by the Chief Plants Officer of the New Zealand Ministry of Agriculture that he had diagnostic evidence that the bacterium (Erwinia amylovora) which can cause the disease fire blight was present in Victorian samples taken and analysed in New Zealand by a New Zealand plant pathologist.
Subsequently, on 16 May 1997 AQIS was similarly notified by the same Chief Plants Officer of diagnostic evidence that the fire blight bacterium was present in South Australia.

(2) Samples which tested positive for fire blight in New Zealand tests and some Australian tests were originally taken from host plants in the Royal Botanic Gardens of Melbourne and the Adelaide Botanic Gardens.
(3) Fire blight in the Royal Botanic Gardens of Melbourne was detected on Cotoneaster plants. In the Adelaide Botanic Gardens it was found on Cotoneaster plants and a Pyracantha plant.

(4) Dr Chris Hale saw symptoms he recognised as consistent with a low level infection on highly susceptible Cotoneaster plants (later confirmed in New Zealand diagnostic tests) in the Royal Botanic Gardens of Melbourne. Dr Hale is a plant pathologist with the Horticulture and Food Research Institute of New Zealand and a fire blight expert very familiar with fire blight symptoms.

In the Adelaide Botanic Gardens, Mr Richard Ivess who is the Chief Plants Officer for the New Zealand Ministry of Agriculture and very familiar with fire blight, saw similar symptoms on two Cotoneaster plants and one Pyracantha plant.

(5) Following extensive field surveying some suspect samples from a number of areas have been sent for laboratory testing. However until tests are completed it is not possible to determine the area of the outbreak.
No suspect symptoms have been reported from Tasmania, Western Australia, Queensland or the Australian Capital Territory.

(6) Fire blight is caused by the bacterium Erwinia amylovora and is distributed short distances by contact and rain splash. Long range dispersal occurs by such mechanisms as the movement of bees, birds or pruning tools or other objects which have come into contact with infected material as well as transport of infected plant material.

(7) The origin of the fire blight bacterium found in Australia has not been established. The results of current diagnostic testing being carried out in Australia have not been consistent with results being carried out in New Zealand and have not been typical of virulent strains of the fire blight bacterium. However, testing is continuing to further define the Erwinia amylovora bacterium found in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 4 June 1 997:

QUESTION.PARA: Will he table on a regular basis details relating to travelling allowance payments made to Ministers and Opposition office holders: if not, why not; if so, what would (a) be his preferred regularity of tabling and (b) the process cost.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is:

ANSWER.PARA: On 17 June 1997 1 advised the House that the Government will, in future, table in the Parliament on a six monthly basis the expenditure details of all Senators and Members' including Ministers and Opposition office holders, on all air and car transport and related travelling allowances.
The cost of this process is yet to be determined but will include assembling and checking the relevant data and printing documents for tabling.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 17 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Have all Government departments and agencies occupying Commonwealth office space been forced to sign commercial leases; if so, (a) why, (b) what are the terms of the leases, (c) do the leases contain provisions for variations in the size or operations of the Department; if so, what and (d) what office space is vacant in Commonwealth buildings in the ACT as a result of these arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: All Government departments and agencies occupying Commonwealth-owned office space, except Government Business Enterprises, are required by a Government decision of December last year to enter into registrable leases for the space occupied, on behalf of the Commonwealth as lessee, on the same basis as they enter into leases for non-Commonwealth-owned space.
(a) The reason for this requirement is to maintain the market value of the properties concerned, and to facilitate their sale.

(b) The terms of the leases are based on normal commercial terms and conditions, and are comparable with those of leases which the Commonwealth has entered into with private-sector landlords. The periods of occupancy vary between one month and ten years, and have been negotiated on the basis of the operational requirements of the individual departments and agencies.

(c) Certain of the leases contain a provision for the Commonwealth as lessee to increase or decrease at its discretion the area occupied by an agreed amount at an agreed date during the term of the lease, provided that notice is given to the lessor by a preceding agreed date.
(d) No Commonwealth-owned office space in the ACT has as yet become vacant due to the operation of an arrangement described in (c) above.
